questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of a painless lump on his penis. He first noticed the lesion 1 year ago but was too embarrassed to mention it at his last annual physical examination. The lesion has since grown in size and has recently become erythematous. At age 45, he was successfully treated for phimosis with a steroid cream. He first engaged in sexual intercourse at age 14 and has had “too many sexual partners to count” in his lifetime. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. Physical examination shows a nontender, ulcerated, 5 × 5 mm lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. Excisional biopsy of the lesion is performed. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on this patient's biopsy specimen?

choices.text: Atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity
Nonspecific inflammatory features with Chlamydia trachomatis amplification on PCR
Multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck smear
Safety pin-shaped intracellular inclusions that appear purple on Giemsa stain

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity are diagnostic of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), the most common carcinoma of the penis. This patient's lesion has been growing for a year now, which should raise suspicion of cancer. Additionally, he has three independent risk factors for SCC of the penis, including phimosis, smoking, and a sexual history that predisposes him to HPV infection. Considering the chronic nature of the lesion and this patient's personal history, his biopsy will most likely show histopathological findings of SCC.

B) INCORRECT:

Spirochetes on dark-field microscopy are diagnostic of syphilis. Although primary syphilis causes painless penile lesions which begin as papules that then ulcerate, these lesions resolve within 3–6 weeks and are associated with inguinal lymphadenopathy. This patient's lesion has been present for at least 1 year and is not associated with lymphadenopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis amplification on PCR may be seen in patients with lymphogranuloma venereum, which can also manifest with painless genital ulcers. However, the onset of genital ulcers is generally acute, and most lesions resolve within a couple of days before progressing to secondary infection with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) and abscess formation. While this patient is at risk for sexually transmitted infections such as C. trachomatis infection, his chronic, slow-growing ulcerative lesion is inconsistent with lymphogranuloma venereum.

D) INCORRECT:

Multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear indicate a herpes simplex virus infection. Genital herpes infection usually manifests with painful red bumps or white vesicles, whereas this patient's lesion is painless. Additionally, herpetic lesions eventually resolve within ∼ 10 days and do not persist and/or worsen over the course of a year.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of Donovan bodies is the characteristic histopathological finding in granuloma inguinale. Although granuloma inguinale also causes chronic, painless, penile lesions, the lesions are typically large, beefy-red with a rolled edge, and bleed easily. This patient's lesion is smaller, without a rolled edge, and there is no history of bleeding.
questions.hint: What disease is most likely to cause a small, chronic, painless, slow-growing ulcerative penile lesion without systemic symptoms or lymphadenopathy in a patient with a history of phimosis, high-risk sexual behavior, and smoking?

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a growth on his penis that has been gradually increasing in size over the past year. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 10 years ago. He has been divorced for 25 years and has had “at least 30 sexual partners” since. Physical examination shows a nontender 2.5-cm ulcerated lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. There is firm left inguinal lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the lesion shows atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, particularly with types 16 and 18, is a known risk factor for carcinoma of the penis. Other risk factors for carcinoma of the penis include phimosis and HIV infection. Although HIV may directly contribute to carcinogenesis, this association may also be due to the frequent HPV co-infection in this patient group. Apart from the immunosuppression enabling the persistence of HPV infection, HIV also seems to directly promote HPV-associated carcinogenesis.

High-risk types of HPV (i.e., 16, 18, 31, 33) are also associated with cervical cancer (almost all cases), as well as anal, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

B) INCORRECT:

EBV is associated with several malignancies such as Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma. However, EBV is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

C) INCORRECT:

HSV-2 is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes genital herpes. Unlike this patient's slowly increasing painless ulcer, genital herpes typically manifests with multiple painful lesions that evolve from vesicles and pustules to ulcers over about 10 days. Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy is common. HSV-2 is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.
Image Description:

Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

D) INCORRECT:

H. ducreyi is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes chancroid. Unlike this patient's presentation, chancroid typically manifests with erythematous papules that become pustular and erode into very painful genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. H. ducreyi is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

E) INCORRECT:

N. gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted pathogen and a common cause of genitourinary infections such as urethritis and epididymitis. None of these infections would cause a gradually increasing ulcerated lesion on the penis. Moreover, they are associated with symptoms such as purulent urethral discharge and dysuria (if urethritis), or scrotal pain and swelling (if epididymitis). N. gonorrhoeae is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

F) INCORRECT:

T. pallidum is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes syphilis. Primary syphilis typically manifests with a solitary, painless ulcer in the genital region (chancre) as well as regional nontender lymphadenopathy. However, the ulcer does not increase gradually but typically heals spontaneously within 3–6 weeks. Systemic symptoms due to secondary syphilis are expected 3–4 months after primary infection. T. pallidum is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

G) INCORRECT:

C. trachomatis is a sexually transmitted pathogen whose serotypes L1–L3 can cause lymphogranuloma venereum. This condition initially manifests with a small, painless ulcer in the genital region. However, the ulcer does not increase gradually but typically heals and disappears within one week. After 2–6 weeks, the extension of the infection to the draining lymph nodes results in painful, suppurative, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever). C. trachomatis is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has carcinoma of the penis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents for evaluation of a painless penile mass that has been progressively growing larger since he first noticed it 6 months ago. He reports having sexual intercourse without condoms with at least three female partners in the past 6 months. He has had no dysuria or hematuria. He reports current tobacco use but has no other significant medical history.
On physical examination, a fungating mass is noted at the right ventral penile glans (figure). There are palpable inguinal lymph nodes bilaterally that are nontender and indurated.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Balanitis is an infectious, inflammatory condition of the penis, usually involving the glans or foreskin. It may be a risk factor for penile carcinoma when chronic but would not cause a fungating mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Genital warts are common, particularly in patients who have multiple sexual partners and do not use condoms. Genital warts share a common risk factor with penile carcinoma (HPV infection) and may also have a fungating appearance (e.g., verrucous condyloma), but they are not associated with adenopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is a cutaneous viral infection mediated by a poxvirus. Although the associated lesions may occur anywhere on the body, including the genitalia, they are painless, small, umbilicated papules, very different in appearance from this patient’s lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

The classic manifestation of syphilis is a painless, round ulcer, which is not present in this case.

E) CORRECT:

Penile carcinoma is a rare squamous-cell cancer that is most frequently encountered in regions of Africa, South America, and Asia. Risk factors include tobacco use, phimosis, lack of circumcision, chronic penile inflammation, poor penile hygiene, immunosuppression, and infection with human papillomavirus (especially HPV 16, HPV 6, and HPV 18). Lesions most typically involve the glans and foreskin and may be described as either velvety erythema (carcinoma in situ) or a fungating or ulcerating mass (invasive carcinoma). Metastatic disease will first manifest in the superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes.

Key learning point: Squamous-cell carcinoma of the penis typically manifests as a fungating or ulcerating mass.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic because of a growth on his penis that has been gradually increasing in size over the past year. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 10 years ago. He has been divorced for 25 years and reports having had at least 30 sexual partners since then. On examination, there is a nontender 2.5-cm ulcerated lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. Firm left inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Biopsy of the lesion reveals atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity. This condition is most likely associated with which one of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

T. pallidum is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes syphilis. Primary syphilis typically manifests with a solitary, painless ulcer in the genital region (chancre) as well as regional nontender lymphadenopathy. However, the ulcer does not increase gradually but typically heals spontaneously within 3–6 weeks. Systemic symptoms due to secondary syphilis are expected 3–4 months after primary infection. T. pallidum is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

B) INCORRECT:

HSV-2 is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes genital herpes. Unlike this patient's slowly increasing painless ulcer, genital herpes typically manifests with multiple painful lesions that evolve from vesicles and pustules to ulcers over about 10 days. Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy is common. HSV-2 is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

C) INCORRECT:

C. trachomatis is a sexually transmitted pathogen whose serotypes L1–L3 can cause lymphogranuloma venereum. This condition initially manifests with a small, painless ulcer in the genital region. However, the ulcer does not increase gradually but typically heals and disappears within one week. After 2–6 weeks, the extension of the infection to the draining lymph nodes results in painful, suppurative, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever). C. trachomatis is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, particularly with types 16 and 18, is a known risk factor for carcinoma of the penis. Apart from the immunosuppression enabling the persistence of HPV infection, HIV also seems to directly promote HPV-associated carcinogenesis.

High-risk types of HPV (i.e., 16, 18, 31, 33) are also associated with cervical cancer (almost all cases), as well as anal, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

Key learning point: Carcinoma of the penis is strongly associated with infection by high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types, especially HPV 16 and 18.

E) INCORRECT:

N. gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted pathogen and a common cause of genitourinary infections such as urethritis and epididymitis. None of these infections would cause a gradually increasing ulcerated lesion on the penis. Moreover, they are associated with symptoms such as purulent urethral discharge and dysuria (if urethritis), or scrotal pain and swelling (if epididymitis). N. gonorrhoeae is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of a painless penile mass that has been progressively increasing in size over the past 6 months. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with at least three female partners during this period. He denies dysuria or hematuria. He currently uses tobacco. On examination, there is a fungating mass at the right ventral penile glans (figure). Bilateral inguinal lymph nodes are palpable, nontender, and indurated. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is a cutaneous viral infection mediated by a poxvirus. Although the associated lesions may occur anywhere on the body, including the genitalia, they are painless, small, umbilicated papules, very different in appearance from this patient’s lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

Balanitis is an infectious, inflammatory condition of the penis, usually involving the glans or foreskin. It may be a risk factor for penile carcinoma when chronic but would not cause a fungating mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Genital warts are common, particularly in patients who have multiple sexual partners and do not use condoms. Genital warts share a common risk factor with penile carcinoma (HPV infection) and may also have a fungating appearance (e.g., verrucous condyloma), but they are not associated with adenopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

The classic manifestation of syphilis is a painless, round ulcer, which is not present in this case.

E) CORRECT:

Penile carcinoma is a rare squamous-cell cancer that is most frequently encountered in regions of Africa, South America, and Asia. Risk factors include tobacco use, phimosis, lack of circumcision, chronic penile inflammation, poor penile hygiene, immunosuppression, and infection with human papillomavirus (especially HPV 16, HPV 6, and HPV 18). Lesions most typically involve the glans and foreskin and may be described as either velvety erythema (carcinoma in situ) or a fungating or ulcerating mass (invasive carcinoma). Metastatic disease will first manifest in the superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes.

Key learning point: Squamous-cell carcinoma of the penis typically manifests as a fungating or ulcerating mass.

questions.text: A 62-year-old uncircumcised man presents to the emergency department with a 4-month history of a painless penile lesion that has been slowly enlarging. He presents today because he has a planned date with a coworker next week and is concerned about the lesion’s appearance. He reports occasional burning but denies dysuria, penile discharge, or erectile dysfunction. Physical examination is shown. Bilateral firm, nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. STI screening has been sent, and the patient will follow up with his primary care physician for the results. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Arrange urgent urologic referral for biopsy and staging
Prescribe topical podophyllin for condyloma acuminata
Give empiric intramuscular benzathine penicillin for suspected condyloma lata
Prescribe oral fluconazole for fungal balanitis
Treat empirically with oral antibiotics for severe bacterial balanitis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct — The image demonstrates an advanced, ulcerative, keratinized lesion typical of squamous cell carcinoma of the penis. In the ED, management involves recognition, control of bleeding or infection if present, and expedited urologic referral for definitive diagnosis and oncologic management.

B) INCORRECT:

Condyloma acuminata from human papillomavirus infection can appear as verrucous or cauliflower-like growths on the genitalia, which may superficially resemble the lesion shown. However, condylomata are typically soft, flesh-colored, and nonulcerated, whereas this lesion demonstrates necrosis, keratinization, and ulceration. Applying topical agents such as podophyllin is contraindicated in this patient's suspected diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Condyloma lata are smooth, white papular erosions typically found in the perianal or intertriginous regions during secondary syphilis. The lesion in the image is ulcerated, keratinized, and exophytic; features that are uncommon in condyloma lata.

D) INCORRECT:

Superficial fungal infections such as candidiasis present with erythematous plaques or white, curd-like exudates on the glans and foreskin but do not form ulcerated, indurated, or keratinized lesions. The extensive necrotic and exophytic appearance in this image is inconsistent with fungal balanitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Balanitis may present with erythema and discharge but does not cause an indurated, keratinized mass as seen in the image.

questions.text: A 68-year-old uncircumcised man presents with a non-healing lesion on his glans penis he first noticed 3 months ago. He reports occasional minor bleeding from the site but denies pain or urinary symptoms. Physical examination reveals a 2-cm indurated, ulcerated plaque on the dorsal aspect of the glans. There is also firm, non-tender right inguinal lymphadenopathy. A biopsy is performed. Infection with which of the following organisms is the most significant risk factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis most commonly causes urethritis. Specific serotypes (L1-L3) cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which may present with a small, transient, painless genital ulcer that often goes unnoticed. The hallmark of LGV is painful, progressive inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), which differs from this patient's non-tender lymph nodes. Chlamydia is not a known causative agent of penile cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Infection with Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which is characterized by one or more deep, painful genital ulcers with ragged borders and a purulent base. This patient's lesion is painless. Additionally, the associated inguinal lymphadenopathy in chancroid is typically tender and can become fluctuant, forming buboes, whereas this patient has firm, non-tender lymph nodes.

C) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation of a chronic, non-healing, indurated, and ulcerated plaque with regional lymphadenopathy in an older, uncircumcised man is classic for squamous cell carcinoma of the penis. A significant risk factor for this malignancy is infection with high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly types 16 and 18. These oncoviruses produce proteins E6 and E7, which inactivate the tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb, respectively, leading to uncontrolled cellular proliferation. Other major risk factors include being uncircumcised, which can lead to chronic inflammation from retained smegma, as well as phimosis and smoking.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus type 2 typically causes recurrent episodes of grouped, painful vesicles that evolve into shallow ulcers and then heal. The lesions are not chronic or progressively enlarging over a 3-month period. Although there is some research exploring a link with certain malignancies, it is not considered the most significant infectious risk factor for penile cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which classically presents in its primary stage with a painless ulcer called a chancre. While this patient has a painless lesion, a syphilitic chancre is typically self-limiting and resolves within 3 to 6 weeks, even without treatment. This patient's lesion has persisted for 3 months. Furthermore, syphilis is not recognized as a direct cause of penile carcinoma.
questions.hint: The patient's chronic, non-healing, indurated lesion, coupled with regional lymphadenopathy, is highly suspicious for a malignancy caused by a sexually transmitted oncovirus.
